AVIATION FUEL QUALITY REQUIREMENTS FOR
JOINTLY OPERATED SYSTEMS
(AFORJOS)
This document has the agreement of: BP, ChevronTexaco, ENl, E>o<onMobil, Kuwait
Petroleum, Shell, Statoil, and Total. lt defines the fuel quality requirements for supply into
Jointly Operated Fuelling Systems.
The Aviation Fuel Quality Requirements for Jointly Operated Systems (AFQRJOS) for
Jet A-l embodies the most stringent requirements of the following two specifications:
(a) British Ministry of Defence Standard DEF STAN 91-91/lssue 5 of I February,
2005 and Amendment 2, dated 9 March 2OO7, for Turbine Fuel, Aviation
Kerosene Type, Jet A-1, NATO Code F-35, Joint Service Designation AVTUR.
(b) ASTM Standard Specification D 1655 - 06d for Aviation Turbine Fuels "Jet A-1."
Jet fuelthat meets the AFQRJOS is usually referred to as "Jet A-1 to Check List", or "Check
List Jet A-1" and, by definition, generally, meets the requirements of both of the above
specifications.
The main table requirements in IATA Guidance Material for Aviation Turbine Fuels
Specifications (GM) are no longer part of the Check List because Part I of the IATA GM is
now a guide to specifications rather than a specification itself. However, the water and dirt
limits for fuel at the point of delivery into aircraft,

f the Check List because Part I of the IATA GM is
now a guide to specifications rather than a specification itself. However, the water and dirt
limits for fuel at the point of delivery into aircraft, which are embodied in Part III of the IATA
GM, remain part of Gheck List.
The Aviation Fuel Quality Requirements for Jointly Operated Systems for Jet A-1 are defined
in the following table that should be read in conjunction with the notes on pages 3 to 5 of this
document. The notes highlight some of the main issues concerning the specification
parameters.
ln principle, conformance to AFQRJOS requires conformance to the detail of both
specificaiions listed above, not just the following table. However, the JIG Product Quality
iommittee that publishes the Gheck List has decided to allow inclusion of some test
methods that are not common to both parent spec!f!cations.
The reasons are that (1) there are some significant differences between the allowed test
methods in DEF STAN 91/91 and ASTM D 1655, (2) there are variations in the availability of
test equipment in different parts of the world and, (3) there is a desire to promote the
adoption of more modern test methods.
Therefore product tested using the test methods listed here meets the requirements
for aviation fuet supply into Jointly Operated Systems. lt does not necessarily meet
the detailed test method requirements of both

uct tested using the test methods listed here meets the requirements
for aviation fuet supply into Jointly Operated Systems. lt does not necessarily meet
the detailed test method requirements of both parent specifications. See Note 21 fo!
guidance on statements declaring conformance to these specifications.
Also, it should be specifically noted that DEF STAN 91-91/5 requires traceability of product
to point of manufacture.

Bulletin No. 12
June 2007
Main Table Notes
The requirement to report Saybolt Colour shall apply at point of manufacture, thus enabling a
colour change in distribution to be quantified. Where the colour of the fuel precludes the use of
the Saybolt Colour test method, then the visual colour shall be reported. Unusual or atypical
colours should also be noted and investigated. For further information on the significance of
colour see Annex E in DEF STAN 9't-91/5.
This limit shall apply at point of manufacture only. For more information on particulate
contamination refer to Annex F of DEF STAN 91-91 lssue 5. For guidance on contamination
limits for into-plane fuelling refer to sth Edition IATA Guidance Material (Part III).
Attention is drawn to DEF STAN 91-91 lssue 5 which approves the Semi-Synthetic Jet Fuel
(SSJF) produced by SASOL under approval reference FS(Air)ssjeU!. l_o1!SJF_ additional
testing requirements apply and reference should be made to lssue 5 of DEF STAN 91-91. This
particular semi-synthetic fuel meets the requirements of this lssue of Check List.
Testing for TotalAromatics has been introduced into DEF STAN 91-91. lt is included in Check
List to promote the adoption of more modern test methods. The DEF STAN note reads:
"Round robin testing has demonstrated the correlation between total aromatics content
measured by lP

cluded in Check
List to promote the adoption of more modern test methods. The DEF STAN note reads:
"Round robin testing has demonstrated the correlation between total aromatics content
measured by lP 156/ASTM D 1319 and lP 436/ASTM D 6379. Bias between the two methods
necessitates different equivalence limits as shown. Testing laboratories are encouraged to
measure and report total aromatics content by the two methods to assist verification of the
correlation. ln cases of dispute lP 156 will be the referee method".
The Doctor Test is an alternative requirement to the Sulphur Mercaptan Content. ln the event of
conflict between the Sulphur Mercaptan and Doctor Test results, the Sulphur Mercaptan result
shallprevail.
The need to report the % vol. of hydroprocessed and severely hydroprocessed components
(including "nil" or "1007o" as appropriate) on refinery Certificates of Quality for Jet A-1 to Check
List derives from DEF STAN 91-91/5. lt relates to:
(a) antioxidant additives - additive dose rate cannot be interpreted unless the proportion of
hydroprocessed fuel is known and therefore recipients of Jet A-1 cannot check or
demonstrate that fuel complies with Check List if this information is omitted from refinery
Certificates of Qual ity,

(b) the requirement to report the volume % of severely hydroprocessed components as part
of the iubricig requirement in DEF STAN 91-91/5. Note that "hydroprocessed" includes
hydrotreated,- hydiofined and hydrocracked. Severely hydroprocessed components are
Oat!neO as petroleum derived hydrocarbons that have been subjected to hydrogen partial
pressure olgreater than 7000 kPa (70 bar or 1015 psi) during manufacture.
ln methods lp 123 and ASTM D 86 all fuels certified to this specification shall be classed as
group 4, with a condenser temperature of zero to 4'C.
There are different requirements for the use of lP 406 or D 2887 as an alternate method
between ASTM D i65b-06 and DEF STAN 91-91/5. ASTM allows the use of simulated
distillation results directly with different limits, while DEF STAN requires a conversion of
simulated distillation resu[s to estimated lP 123 results using Annex G of lP 406. These
a!*erent approaches were taken because of operational considerations rather than technical
considerations; there is no intent that one approach is more restrictive than the other. lf lP 406
is the method used to generate 1P123 extrapolated data, there is no requirement to_ report
residue or loss. lP 12i extrapolated data may also be used for the calculation of Specific
Energy using ASTM D 3338.
Subject to

to generate 1P123 extrapolated data, there is no requirement to_ report
residue or loss. lP 12i extrapolated data may also be used for the calculation of Specific
Energy using ASTM D 3338.
Subject to a minimum of 40"C, results obtained by method ASTM D 56 (Tag) may be accepted.
These automatic methods are allowed by DEF STAN 91-91/5. lP 16/ASTM D 2386 remains
the referee method.
ASTM D 4529/lP 381 may be used where local regulations permit'
Examination of the heater tube to determine the Visual Tube Rating using the Visual Tuberator
shall be carried out within 120 minutes of completion of the test. lt is the Visual Tube Rating
that should be reported. Attention is drawn to Note 10 in DEF STAN 91-91/5, which stresses
that only approved heater tubes shall be used and lists JFTOT tubes from PAC-Alcor as being
technically suitable.
Attention is drawn to Note 13 of DEF STAN 91-91/5 that states "No precision data are available
for fuels containing SDA; if MSEP testing is carried out during downstream distribution, no
sfecification limitsapply and the results are not to be used as the sole reason for rejection of a
fuel".
Due to the requirements of DEF STAN 91-91/5, Conductivity limits are mandatory for product to
meet this speoification. However it is acknowledged that in some manufacturing and distribution
systems it is more practical to inject SDA further downstream. ln such cases

e mandatory for product to
meet this speoification. However it is acknowledged that in some manufacturing and distribution
systems it is more practical to inject SDA further downstream. ln such cases the Certificate of
GIuality for the batcir should be annotated thus: "Product meets the requirements of AFQRJOS
Check List 22 except for electrical conductivity". Due to the high flow ratgs 3p very fine
filtration used when iuelling aircraft, it is absolutely essential that these conductivity limits are
met at the point of delivery to aircraft.
This requirement comes from DEF STAN 91-91/5. The requirement to determine lubricity
applies ang to fuels containing more than 95% hydroprocessed material and where at least
il1l" i" severely hydroprocess-eO lsee NOTE 6 above) and for all fuels containing synthetic
components. Ind limit applies only at the point of manufacture. For important advisory
information on the lubricity'of aviation turbine fuels see Annex B of DEF STAN 91-91/5.
ct/Lt additive may be used to improve lubricity; only those 1d!r!ves listed in Table 2 of ASTM
D165S-06d are permitted. Refer also to Appendix A.4 of DEF STAN 91-91/5 Am2 for advice on
point of addition. \A/hen injecting Cl/Ll downstream of point of manufacture, care must be taken
to ensure that maximum dose rates are not exceeded.

The approved Metal Deactivator Additive (MDA), RDE/A/650 appears in Annex A.2.2 of DEF
srn!!'gt-gt/5. see also Annex A.2.1 about the need to report thermal stability before and after
usinf wnen contamination of Jet A-1 by any of the trace metals listed in this Annex is unproven.
Note also in A.2.3 that maximum Oothing'at the point of manufacture or on initial doping is
limited to 2mg/1.

concentrations of Fuel system lcing lnhibitor (FSll) less than 0.02o/o by volume can be
considered negligible and ?o not require agreemenUnotific_atio.n. The assent to allow these
smatt quantitieo ot FSll without agreemenunot!Rcation is to facilitate the changeover from fuels
aont"ining FSll to those not containing FSll where the additive may remain in the fuel system
for a limitad time. This does not allow the continuous FSll addition at these low concentrations.
Attention is drawn to the guidance in DEF STAN 91-91 lssue 5

e additive may remain in the fuel system
for a limitad time. This does not allow the continuous FSll addition at these low concentrations.
Attention is drawn to the guidance in DEF STAN 91-91 lssue 5 and ASTM D 1655-06d
concerning the need for appropriate management of - change measures in refineries
manufactui!ng jet fuel. fne imthiications of any Changes-to feedstock, processing conditions or
process addiiues on finished product quality and therformance need to be considered (for
axampte, experience has shown that some throcess additives might be carried over in trace
quantities into aviation fuels).
It is normal to certify conformance to specifications with statements like "lt is certified that the
samples have been tested using the Test Methods stated and that the Batch represented by
ine Eampres conforms to nFeRios checktist lssue 22. \Mrere applicable, Batch.certificates
may atso confirm, specifically, compliance with DEF STAN 91-91 (latest issue) and/or ASTM D
1655 (latest issue).
